title: The Key 2 Time â€” The Judgement of Isskar
author: Simon

elements.text: [Part One]
Thunder and rain.
Peri? Can you hear me? Peri. Peri!
Beeps.
Come on, come on. You're meant to be a compass. Is that north or north by north-west? Oh. Good afternoon.
Good afternoon.
Rain stops.
Thank you. I assume you did that?
Did what?
Stopped it raining? On a planet where the rain never stops.
The rain hasn't stopped.
Oh no. You've stopped Time. The rain's just hanging in the air. I notice you're not wet at all and you don't have an umbrella. I wish I did.
(laughs) You must be the Doctor.
Yes. Hello. You... you're not hurt and your clothes aren't torn so I'm guessing you're not a survivor from one of the crashed ships here. Who are you?
I don't know. How would I tell?
Good question. But you were expecting me.
I was made to expect you.
Someone's forcing you?
No. I was made, built to expect you, by The Grace.
The Grace? They sound like they should have better manners.
I need your help, Doctor.
Well, I'm always keen to help. So, who are The Grace? I assume they're the ones who stopped Time?
Yes.
So they're probably huge and pan-dimensional with amazing powers our universe can barely conceive and yet they need me to run an errand.
No. They want me to find three of the segments of the Key to Time. / want you to help me.
What, as a sort of assistant?
Yes.
Well, obviously I'm flattered. Hang on. You said the Key to Time.

Yes. Like me, it was built by the Grace. The Key to Time is a perfect cube which maintains the equilibrium of Time itself. When its six crystal segments are assembled, it can stop and start the universe. It can re-write matter and change the states of quanta. It can restore balance.
And the six crystal segments are currently scattered through all Time and Space, disguised as anything and anyone.
Yes.
Thought so. And you just need to find three of the six pieces.
Yes. Just three of them.
Well, forget it. I'm busy.
Doing what?
Lots of things. Have you seen a young woman wandering about lost? She'd be in the least practical clothes.
Your woman can wait. Time has stopped here until you get back from helping me.
I'd sooner find out while I'm here. The storm makes it hard to tell where you are and she lacks my unerring sense of direction and of course this compass.
That's not a compass.
Yes, I was coming to that conclusion myself. Still, it led me to you. Oh. It's not a compass, is it?
That's what I said.

It was there in the wreckage of a ship called The Green Man's Burden and I just picked it up. Me, I don't need a compass but something about it... Did the Grace bring the Tardis here? I thought the controls were being sticky.
Give the compass to me.
How do I know I can trust you?
What? But you know about the Key to Time, don't you?
Yes I do, but how do I know that you don't want it for the wrong reasons?
I... don't know.
How do I know you're not an agent of the Black Guardian? He's tried to trick me like this before. So how do I know I can trust you? You really don't know, do you?
No.
Say please.
Please.
All right, since you asked so nicely you can have the compass.
Thank you.
But we'll need to convert it from a compass back into a crystal segment. When I did this last time I had a Tracer thing.
Crackling and power build-up. Whumph.
One crystal segment.
Very clever. You are a Tracer, aren't you? That saves a lot of mucking about. Does it tickle?
(laughs) Oh. It tickles. My nose feels all tickly.
I remember the first time Nyssa tried chocolate. Look, careful, you're going to drop it.
No I'm not. I'm going to put it in my satchel.
Your satchel?
The inside is in a different universe, with amazing powers this universe can barely conceive.
And such a pretty colour. So what, once they're in the satchel, no-one can touch them?
Yes. Though I can feel it in there.
And it will be safe in there?
Safe from what?
This universe can be a bit dangerous and unpredictable. You're quite naive, aren't you?
I'm only four minutes old. Do you mean the Guardians? I'm not meant to involve them.
The two Guardians are elemental forces with who knows what kind of powers. They're the ones who wanted the Key to Time before. They could help.
They could make things more difficult.
True. But like everyone else, the Key to Time offers amazing unimaginable power. They're drawn to it.
You're not?
Oh, I am. I'm tempted to make things better for everyone, force people to get along and have a nice time.
But that would be good, wouldn't it?
You can't be a benevolent dictator. Force is always force.
The Grace can force you to help me.
And squish me with just a thought. I'm sure they can.
But they don't want you involved.
Oh? Why not?
They know the sort of life you have. You're a bit dangerous and unpredictable. But I think that's why you can help me.
Because I have practical experience. The remaining two segments will be disguised, part of the places where they're hidden.
Other people will be drawn to them, and I'm quite naive, so I won't be safe, will 1?
All right, I'll make you a deal. I'll help you find one segment, then you'll have the hang of it and you can find the other one yourself. I come back here to find my friend.
It's a deal.
I assume we're taking my ship. Come on. Do you have a name?
No. You could call me Peri.
Why would I do that?
Or Doctor. I don't know any other names.
I'm sorry. Everyone should have their own name, and there's plenty to choose from. A... Abigail? Acacia? Acantha?
Door opens.
You'll stop me when you like one.
/f I like one.
[OC]: You'll like one. Adda? Addama? Adella? Adelaide?
Door closes.
Adiambo...
The Tardis dematerialises.
The Tardis materialises, door opens.
Amethyst. Amira? Amritha? Amy?
Oh. That's amazing.
All right, Amy it is. Amy.
Huh? Oh no. I mean this place. It's... I guess it's warm. I've not been warm before.

It would be even warmer without all these pools and fountains. They're a central cooling system for this whole... I think it's a fortified town on Medina, and they've been having a fiesta, judging by the state of the place. Someone is probably nursing a hangover instead of tidying up.
See? I knew you'd know this sort of thing. Saves me having to look it all up.
Well, if instead of just taking control of my ship you'd let me set some coordinates, we'd know where we are.
I'm sorry.
Are you?
Yes, I think so.
Well, good. Come on, now it's your turn to be the clever one. Where's the second segment?
Er, my nose is more tickly... in that direction.
Well, let's go over there, then. Mind the broken roof-tiles. Whoops! Less gravity than I'm used to. I need heavier shoes. Just look at that.
What is it?
What does it look like? Some kind of flying car or skiff. Just look at the magnetic drive. Probably makes it very nippy and manoeuvrable. Keep up, Amy.
Why the hurry? I thought you liked this sort of thing.
Mooching round new places, seeing what's to see? I suppose I do like doing that, but I want to get the second segment and be out of here before... Quick!
You're squishing me.
Shh! I think he saw us.
Oh. Who did?
You there.
Oh no. He's seen us. Let me do the talking. Good afternoon.
Do you know that man?
It's an Ice Warrior.
Oh.
You are aliens.
Yes, but nice ones. Hello. I'm the Doctor and this is my friend Amy.
I didn't say I liked that name.
Shush. Don't worry about her, she's only ten minutes old.
There are rules for dealing with aliens.
I'm sure there are. Look, we don't want to cause any bother.
Can I offer you water?
Thank you. I think we're both fine. Don't want to be greedy, do we, Amy?
Aren't you meant to be a warrior?
I do not know what warrior is, but I am keen to assist you if I can.
Oh, well, that's very decent of you. We just fancied a bit of a wander, stretch our legs, see what's what, dawdle idly. We don't want to put you to any trouble.
It is given freely, but I recommend you try the market before it closes.
The market? Right.
Ah, there's a good view of the vast pyramid there, and I think it is probably the best market on Mars.
Sorry, did you say Mars?
It's incredible. There's so many people. Talking, working, playing music. Those two are kissing.

I've only ever been to Mars when the Martians were long gone. Joined a NASA mission, no, not that long ago. And there was that archaeological project in 2560 er, something. But you're right. Vibrant, convivial, and peaceable. A species who can't abide what we call room temperature, and they've built a town right on the equator.
Is that clever?

The shell-like buildings reflect the heat. I guess the splits in them let the heat out too. And the canals and waterways keep the air cool. If I remember the write-up from the dig, the whole of Mars had been criss-crossed with intricate waterways. Despite their susceptibility to heat, Martians lived all over the surface of their planet.
(female) Would you like water, alien? It's given freely.
It's very kind of you, Madam, but we have an appointment.
No we don't.
With the second segment. How's your tickly nose?
It's tickly. I think it must be right in front of us towards that... Oh.
Towards that vast pyramid they've nearly completed. Well, that's not very ostentatious, is it? Least they won't notice us stealing that.
It's not the pyramid.
Well, that makes things easier.
It's the capstone on the top.
Oh. Well, it'll be a simple job to clamber all the way up there and take it, with only everyone able to see us. Are you all right?
The segment. It's not just tickly.
Amy, what is it?
I... don't know what the word is. Oh no, not again.
An earthquake. You idiot, Doctor, not a fiesta, an earthquake!
It's tickling in my head.
Amy, come on, we've got to find somewhere safe.
It's the segment.
We've got to get away from the buildings. They're liable to fall!
There's another one under here. I can see his feet. Quick. Okay. Everyone lift at once.
Three, two, one.
That's it. That's it, he's... Oh.
He is dead.

It's all right, honestly. I'm a Doctor. No, no, no. Let me see. Your shell's cracked. I think some sand's got in. That's irritating where you're wounded. Agonising, I expect, but not life-threatening. Okay, I'm going to have to get you on a stretcher. Okay. Good. You're being very brave. These two helpful fellas are going to take you to the apothecary. They'll be as gentle as they can be. Now, keep his leg raised. He's lost a lot of blood.
Thank you, alien.
It's given freely. Ah, Amy. I think I'm done here. How are you feeling?
Oh. I'm good.
You don't seem to have broken anything. You don't even seem to be bruised.
I got some dust in my eye but I blinked and it fell out. You've got blood coming out of you.
Yes, I'd noticed. We think six Martians died.
I don't... I don't like that.
No. No, no, but it could have been much worse, and we helped the ones we could.
They kept offering to get me water.
Yes, yes, me too. It's a gift economy. They don't buy things, they give them away. It's all wrapped up in a code of honour, like Christmas cards.
I don't understand.
Oh, er, well, you send Christmas cards out to everyone, and it's on their honour to send you a Christmas card back.
And, what, that's not how markets work normally?

Not everywhere, no. I thought they were soldiers, but they're more like an arts and crafts commune, swapping goods as they're needed. They've got theatre and science and what I think is a kind of political singing.
And they don't know what warrior means. They've never had any wars.
No. Martians learn to fight, to hunt animals for food, but they don't fight one another, at least not yet. It's er, well, it's not what I was expecting.
We could stay if you like, for a while.
We need to get that second segment. It was what caused the earthquake, wasn't it? Wasn't it?
Something isn't right.
Come on. We don't want anyone else to suffer.
But we can't just go up there and take it. Someone will see.
Well, we'll just have to make sure they don't notice us.
Alien.
Oh. Er, yes?
You and your female are under arrest.
Go on, Doctor, guess.
Er, twelve thousand.
More.
Thirteen thousand.
More.
Forty eight million billion, fifteen thousand and six.
Ah. (laughs) Fewer. The vast pyramid has employed nineteen thousand literate masons, six hundred carpenters and forty six overseers, as well as the providence of the old Gods.
Hmn, yes, I recognise their influence in the apothem. It's built for the golden ratio, isn't it? A plus Bis to Aas Ais to B.
Indeed, Doctor.
A ratio of one to one point six one eight oh three nine eight...
More or less, yes.
You are both literates.
And numerates, Isskar. I've seen that ratio written all across the universe from sequences in DNA to the hearts of stars.
The Grace use it to measure integrals...
I'm sure the Magistrate doesn't need to know.
Oh yes. Sorry.
We understand the numbers, so the pyramid cannot be the cause of the earthquakes. Our engineers would not allow it.
I'm sure they didn't mean to. You say earthquakes, plural.
They started when our moons were half their weight. In the last few days there have been more of them. But with less effect, it is passing.
Is it? You know the story of the Hubris of Jebb? A nut raining wet fire on his house for a year but he refused to admit it.
Did the Old Gods teach your people astronomy too, Doctor?
Actually we taught... Er, we taught ourselves. Though from the same first principles. Observation, evidence.
(laughs.) The Ice Lords in the North should meet you. You're not like the reports.
Not all aliens are the same, Isskar.
No. But my own beadles described you as thieves.
They can't mean us.
A male and a female without scales.
You don't get many alien visitors around here, do you?
No.
What is it?
Most species are wary of strangers. It's a good survival instinct. We've been singled out.
You'll understand if my beadles keep a watch on you.
Oh, I understand perfectly.
And you'll stay away from the vast pyramid. The building site is restricted.
But we have to get the sec...
We understand, Magistrate Isskar.
But Doctor, we need the...
Trespass will be punished severely.

Yes, I rather thought it would. Thank you, Magistrate. You've been very kind. We've taken up far too much of your time and we should get on with our dawdling about. I'll bet there's some lovely boutiques as yet undiscovered where we can find some... postcards. Come on, Amy.
Oh. Thank you for the water.
It was given freely.
I don't understand. He let us go.
They're reasonable people, Amy. He was just giving us fair warning.
But you told him we wouldn't go near the pyramid.
I said I understood. If we get caught they'll treat us severely.
But we don't have any choice.
There's always a choice, Amy.
Crashing.
No there's not. There's going to be another earthquake!
Rumble.
Not if we can help it. Come on.
But Doctor...
What?
The building site? The entrance is over here.
Oh. Right. Well, after you.
Get to the shelters. Move, quickly.
There's nobody left in here.
Only an idiot goes into a building site in the middle of an earthquake. Come on, we need to be the other side of this fence.
There's always the door. It doesn't open.
Here, let me try. One day I must fix myself another sonic screwdriver. It would save me so much time.
Crash.
I thought you said we had to do this quietly.
So I did. After you.
What if there are Martians in there?
Then we'll tell them Isskar sent us.
But he didn't.
No, but they don't need to know that. What?
My nose is tickly.
That's because we're getting near the segment. Just have a bit of a climb.
No, it's not that. It's different. I think there's someone else here.
Someone's coming. Hide. We'll let them go past then we'll carry on.
Okay.
Get off me!
Trespassers will be punished severely.
We're not doing anything. We're tourists. You don't do this to tourists.
But that's...
Amy, wait! Come back.
We have to help her.
Save it for the beadle. He has more patience than me.
But we just wanted to take a photograph. Isn't that right, Zinc?
That's right.
Zinc? You're choking him, you clumsy oaf.
I am trying not to, but he keeps struggling. If you'd both just...
Let them go!
Amy, stop it, this won't do us any good. He's not trying to hurt them.
That's what I was trying to explain to the short man. You aliens are small, soft-boned and fragile.
No - no, wait!
Thump. Thud.
You killed him.
You killed him! Well done, Zinc.
He had it coming. Said I was small.
You killed him.
Yes, he's dead, Amy. I think Isskar mistook us for these two. You must be the thieves.
You should watch what you're accusing people of, Mister. I don't like name-calling. And I'm the one with the gun.
Yes, so you are. Please let Amy go, she's nothing to you.
(laughs) Amy. Have you got yourself a name?
I didn't say I liked it.
You know these people, do you?
Her, not him.
Oh, charming. You should be more like your big sister.
You're sisters?
Not really.
It's the simplest way to explain it.
And you can see the family resemblance. Same eyes, same cheekbones, same clever school-bags.
You're after the other three segments, are you?
Not found any yet. Have you?
We've got one.
That means the one here is mine. It's only fair.
I'm sure there's enough segments for everyone.
And you are...? Oh. Oh, it's you.
Sorry, you've got me at a disadvantage. I'm the Doctor.
I knew it. I Knew she'd pick you up. The Grace said he'd be trouble...
I needed an assistant.
And so did I. But I didn't feel the need to hunt down the one guy who...
All right! He's been useful. He knows how to do this stuff.
Er, Amy, we should be going.
Yeah. They'll be back here soon enough. We can't be near the body.
Let's go.
Amy, come on. Amy, you can't stay here.
They killed him. They killed him.
I know. But if we stay here they'll think it was us. Come on.
Once we leave the cover of the scaffolding, everyone can see us.
It looks like another... hundred metres to the top.
Ninety eight... So, ninety eight more of these... Oh, I guess they're too big to call steps?
Yes well, little bracing exercise, good for the circulation.
Oh, you're kidding.
Ninety seven. And then we've got to work out an escape plan too.
Oh, amateurs.
What's that meant to mean?
I assume you have a plan, Mister... I'm sorry, I don't know your name.
Harmonious Fourteen Zinc.
Ah, from the Commune of the White Sun.
Yeah, originally. Haven't been home in years. Why bother when you can go anywhere and when.
I've always thought so.
Yeah.

Though I did like the White Sun's tree-houses. Spent a week in Hauldon. Mostly being accused of blotting out the sunlight, which was just an unhappy coincidence, but... apart from being imprisoned and threatened with various kinds of torture... lovely people, I thought.
Yeah.
So, you haven't told him, then?
I didn't think it would help.
He'll find out soon enough.
Maybe.
And he'll leave you to it, because you lied. He'll leave you.
He's not like your one.
Zinc has taught me a lot.
I can see that. You're... well, I can see him in your eyes and how you move. Has he given you a name?
What do I want a name for?
Everyone should have their own name. Isn't that right, Doctor?
What's that?
She should have a name.
I don't want a name.
She's a construct. She's not real.
But she's still a she. A name will help her build an identity, become someone real. So, starting with A.
But that's the same as me.
All right, er... Z. Z, er... Zoe. I used to know a Zoe. Zinnia. Zillah. Zena. Er, Zelda, Zynab, Zara...
Zara was my mum's name.
It's a nice name. It means Princess.
Oh, go on then, I'll have that one. Just to shut you up.
Stop.
Doctor!
Yes, yes, I can see him. Need to get a move on. Sixty four steps to go.
He's faster than we are.
Never seen Martians move so quickly. Must be the low gravity, their natural environment.
So he'll catch us.
I've still got my gun.
Can I see that?
You want to do the honours? Here.
Whoops! Oh, butterfingers.
You did that on purpose.
You would have used it again.
My wife gave me that gun.
How romantic. Sorry. Enough people have died.
And you might have just killed us.
Not if you've got an escape route. What do you use, if you don't mind my asking?
I think you're in the same game. See this?
A bracelet.
It's a time ring. Picked it up on Barampa. The VP Party had it in a museum, thought it was just ceremonial. So I er, I borrowed it.
I see. So why not materialise on the capstone itself, grab the segment and dash off again?
Oh, that's what we've been trying to do.
Something skews the coordinates. One time we found ourselves six weeks out, and in the middle of a desert.
Amateurs.
Don't get cocky. I've only ever used this thing with two.
A short hop won't hurt it. Drop us in the market. we have our own transport.
What, some sort of a capsule?
It's a retro thing. So what do you say? We are family after all.
Long as I get this segment.
Yes, you get the segment.
Good. Come on, we're almost there.
No we're not.
Stop, or I will shoot you.
Just climb.
My head. It's in my head.
Got to... got to get nearer.
Almost there. Just keep going.
Your final warning.
Ice Warrior gun firing.
Get a move on!
I can't!
The capstone. What's happened to it?
There is nowhere you can run.
I can't get near it.
But it's not there. It's out of reach.
But I can see it. I can... Ow! Ah!
Careful. It's a long way down.
Yeah. And look. From here you can see the shockwaves, rippling through the canals and waterways.
The segment is causing the earthquake.
We have to stop it.
But we can't touch it.
There's something wrong with the segments, isn't there? That's why you needed to fetch them back in.
They're decaying. Their powers are warping.
Raise your arms. I will shoot any one of you.
It's imploding. Forming a gravity well. Maybe a black hole.
It'll destroy Mars.
You are my prisoners. You will not destroy Mars.
Oh, Mars is the least of our worries. If the Key to Time collapses, the universe is finished.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: Peri? Can you hear me? Peri. Peri!
DOCTOR: Come on, come on. You're meant to be a compass. Is that north or north by north-west? Oh. Good afternoon.
AMY: Good afternoon.
DOCTOR: Thank you. I assume you did that?
AMY: Did what?
DOCTOR: Stopped it raining? On a planet where the rain never stops.
AMY: The rain hasn't stopped.
DOCTOR: Oh no. You've stopped Time. The rain's just hanging in the air. I notice you're not wet at all and you don't have an umbrella. I wish I did.
AMY: (laughs) You must be the Doctor.
DOCTOR: Yes. Hello. You... you're not hurt and your clothes aren't torn so I'm guessing you're not a survivor from one of the crashed ships here. Who are you?
AMY: I don't know. How would I tell?
DOCTOR: Good question. But you were expecting me.
AMY: I was made to expect you.
DOCTOR: Someone's forcing you?
AMY: No. I was made, built to expect you, by The Grace.
DOCTOR: The Grace? They sound like they should have better manners.
AMY: I need your help, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Well, I'm always keen to help. So, who are The Grace? I assume they're the ones who stopped Time?
AMY: Yes.
DOCTOR: So they're probably huge and pan-dimensional with amazing powers our universe can barely conceive and yet they need me to run an errand.
AMY: No. They want me to find three of the segments of the Key to Time. / want you to help me.
DOCTOR: What, as a sort of assistant?
AMY: Yes.
DOCTOR: Well, obviously I'm flattered. Hang on. You said the Key to Time.
AMY: Yes. Like me, it was built by the Grace. The Key to Time is a perfect cube which maintains the equilibrium of Time itself. When its six crystal segments are assembled, it can stop and start the universe. It can re-write matter and change the states of quanta. It can restore balance.
DOCTOR: And the six crystal segments are currently scattered through all Time and Space, disguised as anything and anyone.
AMY: Yes.
DOCTOR: Thought so. And you just need to find three of the six pieces.
AMY: Yes. Just three of them.
DOCTOR: Well, forget it. I'm busy.
AMY: Doing what?
DOCTOR: Lots of things. Have you seen a young woman wandering about lost? She'd be in the least practical clothes.
AMY: Your woman can wait. Time has stopped here until you get back from helping me.
DOCTOR: I'd sooner find out while I'm here. The storm makes it hard to tell where you are and she lacks my unerring sense of direction and of course this compass.
AMY: That's not a compass.
DOCTOR: Yes, I was coming to that conclusion myself. Still, it led me to you. Oh. It's not a compass, is it?
AMY: That's what I said.
DOCTOR: It was there in the wreckage of a ship called The Green Man's Burden and I just picked it up. Me, I don't need a compass but something about it... Did the Grace bring the Tardis here? I thought the controls were being sticky.
AMY: Give the compass to me.
DOCTOR: How do I know I can trust you?
AMY: What? But you know about the Key to Time, don't you?
DOCTOR: Yes I do, but how do I know that you don't want it for the wrong reasons?
AMY: I... don't know.
DOCTOR: How do I know you're not an agent of the Black Guardian? He's tried to trick me like this before. So how do I know I can trust you? You really don't know, do you?
AMY: No.
DOCTOR: Say please.
AMY: Please.
DOCTOR: All right, since you asked so nicely you can have the compass.
AMY: Thank you.
DOCTOR: But we'll need to convert it from a compass back into a crystal segment. When I did this last time I had a Tracer thing.
AMY: One crystal segment.
DOCTOR: Very clever. You are a Tracer, aren't you? That saves a lot of mucking about. Does it tickle?
AMY: (laughs) Oh. It tickles. My nose feels all tickly.
DOCTOR: I remember the first time Nyssa tried chocolate. Look, careful, you're going to drop it.
AMY: No I'm not. I'm going to put it in my satchel.
DOCTOR: Your satchel?
AMY: The inside is in a different universe, with amazing powers this universe can barely conceive.
DOCTOR: And such a pretty colour. So what, once they're in the satchel, no-one can touch them?
AMY: Yes. Though I can feel it in there.
DOCTOR: And it will be safe in there?
AMY: Safe from what?
DOCTOR: This universe can be a bit dangerous and unpredictable. You're quite naive, aren't you?
AMY: I'm only four minutes old. Do you mean the Guardians? I'm not meant to involve them.
DOCTOR: The two Guardians are elemental forces with who knows what kind of powers. They're the ones who wanted the Key to Time before. They could help.
AMY: They could make things more difficult.
DOCTOR: True. But like everyone else, the Key to Time offers amazing unimaginable power. They're drawn to it.
AMY: You're not?
DOCTOR: Oh, I am. I'm tempted to make things better for everyone, force people to get along and have a nice time.
AMY: But that would be good, wouldn't it?
DOCTOR: You can't be a benevolent dictator. Force is always force.
AMY: The Grace can force you to help me.
DOCTOR: And squish me with just a thought. I'm sure they can.
AMY: But they don't want you involved.
DOCTOR: Oh? Why not?
AMY: They know the sort of life you have. You're a bit dangerous and unpredictable. But I think that's why you can help me.
DOCTOR: Because I have practical experience. The remaining two segments will be disguised, part of the places where they're hidden.
AMY: Other people will be drawn to them, and I'm quite naive, so I won't be safe, will 1?
DOCTOR: All right, I'll make you a deal. I'll help you find one segment, then you'll have the hang of it and you can find the other one yourself. I come back here to find my friend.
AMY: It's a deal.
DOCTOR: I assume we're taking my ship. Come on. Do you have a name?
AMY: No. You could call me Peri.
DOCTOR: Why would I do that?
AMY: Or Doctor. I don't know any other names.
DOCTOR: I'm sorry. Everyone should have their own name, and there's plenty to choose from. A... Abigail? Acacia? Acantha?
DOCTOR: You'll stop me when you like one.
AMY: /f I like one.
DOCTOR: [OC]: You'll like one. Adda? Addama? Adella? Adelaide?
DOCTOR: Adiambo...
DOCTOR: Amethyst. Amira? Amritha? Amy?
AMY: Oh. That's amazing.
DOCTOR: All right, Amy it is. Amy.
AMY: Huh? Oh no. I mean this place. It's... I guess it's warm. I've not been warm before.
DOCTOR: It would be even warmer without all these pools and fountains. They're a central cooling system for this whole... I think it's a fortified town on Medina, and they've been having a fiesta, judging by the state of the place. Someone is probably nursing a hangover instead of tidying up.
AMY: See? I knew you'd know this sort of thing. Saves me having to look it all up.
DOCTOR: Well, if instead of just taking control of my ship you'd let me set some coordinates, we'd know where we are.
AMY: I'm sorry.
DOCTOR: Are you?
AMY: Yes, I think so.
DOCTOR: Well, good. Come on, now it's your turn to be the clever one. Where's the second segment?
AMY: Er, my nose is more tickly... in that direction.
DOCTOR: Well, let's go over there, then. Mind the broken roof-tiles. Whoops! Less gravity than I'm used to. I need heavier shoes. Just look at that.
AMY: What is it?
DOCTOR: What does it look like? Some kind of flying car or skiff. Just look at the magnetic drive. Probably makes it very nippy and manoeuvrable. Keep up, Amy.
AMY: Why the hurry? I thought you liked this sort of thing.
DOCTOR: Mooching round new places, seeing what's to see? I suppose I do like doing that, but I want to get the second segment and be out of here before... Quick!
AMY: You're squishing me.
DOCTOR: Shh! I think he saw us.
AMY: Oh. Who did?
ICE WARRIOR: You there.
DOCTOR: Oh no. He's seen us. Let me do the talking. Good afternoon.
AMY: Do you know that man?
DOCTOR: It's an Ice Warrior.
AMY: Oh.
ICE WARRIOR: You are aliens.
DOCTOR: Yes, but nice ones. Hello. I'm the Doctor and this is my friend Amy.
AMY: I didn't say I liked that name.
DOCTOR: Shush. Don't worry about her, she's only ten minutes old.
ICE WARRIOR: There are rules for dealing with aliens.
DOCTOR: I'm sure there are. Look, we don't want to cause any bother.
ICE WARRIOR: Can I offer you water?
DOCTOR: Thank you. I think we're both fine. Don't want to be greedy, do we, Amy?
AMY: Aren't you meant to be a warrior?
ICE WARRIOR: I do not know what warrior is, but I am keen to assist you if I can.
DOCTOR: Oh, well, that's very decent of you. We just fancied a bit of a wander, stretch our legs, see what's what, dawdle idly. We don't want to put you to any trouble.
ICE WARRIOR: It is given freely, but I recommend you try the market before it closes.
DOCTOR: The market? Right.
ICE WARRIOR: Ah, there's a good view of the vast pyramid there, and I think it is probably the best market on Mars.
DOCTOR: Sorry, did you say Mars?
AMY: It's incredible. There's so many people. Talking, working, playing music. Those two are kissing.
DOCTOR: I've only ever been to Mars when the Martians were long gone. Joined a NASA mission, no, not that long ago. And there was that archaeological project in 2560 er, something. But you're right. Vibrant, convivial, and peaceable. A species who can't abide what we call room temperature, and they've built a town right on the equator.
AMY: Is that clever?
DOCTOR: The shell-like buildings reflect the heat. I guess the splits in them let the heat out too. And the canals and waterways keep the air cool. If I remember the write-up from the dig, the whole of Mars had been criss-crossed with intricate waterways. Despite their susceptibility to heat, Martians lived all over the surface of their planet.
ICE WARRIOR: (female) Would you like water, alien? It's given freely.
DOCTOR: It's very kind of you, Madam, but we have an appointment.
AMY: No we don't.
DOCTOR: With the second segment. How's your tickly nose?
AMY: It's tickly. I think it must be right in front of us towards that... Oh.
DOCTOR: Towards that vast pyramid they've nearly completed. Well, that's not very ostentatious, is it? Least they won't notice us stealing that.
AMY: It's not the pyramid.
DOCTOR: Well, that makes things easier.
AMY: It's the capstone on the top.
DOCTOR: Oh. Well, it'll be a simple job to clamber all the way up there and take it, with only everyone able to see us. Are you all right?
AMY: The segment. It's not just tickly.
DOCTOR: Amy, what is it?
AMY: I... don't know what the word is. Oh no, not again.
DOCTOR: An earthquake. You idiot, Doctor, not a fiesta, an earthquake!
AMY: It's tickling in my head.
DOCTOR: Amy, come on, we've got to find somewhere safe.
AMY: It's the segment.
DOCTOR: We've got to get away from the buildings. They're liable to fall!
AMY: There's another one under here. I can see his feet. Quick. Okay. Everyone lift at once.
ICE WARRIOR: Three, two, one.
AMY: That's it. That's it, he's... Oh.
ICE WARRIOR: He is dead.
DOCTOR: It's all right, honestly. I'm a Doctor. No, no, no. Let me see. Your shell's cracked. I think some sand's got in. That's irritating where you're wounded. Agonising, I expect, but not life-threatening. Okay, I'm going to have to get you on a stretcher. Okay. Good. You're being very brave. These two helpful fellas are going to take you to the apothecary. They'll be as gentle as they can be. Now, keep his leg raised. He's lost a lot of blood.
ICE WARRIOR: Thank you, alien.
DOCTOR: It's given freely. Ah, Amy. I think I'm done here. How are you feeling?
AMY: Oh. I'm good.
DOCTOR: You don't seem to have broken anything. You don't even seem to be bruised.
AMY: I got some dust in my eye but I blinked and it fell out. You've got blood coming out of you.
DOCTOR: Yes, I'd noticed. We think six Martians died.
AMY: I don't... I don't like that.
DOCTOR: No. No, no, but it could have been much worse, and we helped the ones we could.
AMY: They kept offering to get me water.
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, me too. It's a gift economy. They don't buy things, they give them away. It's all wrapped up in a code of honour, like Christmas cards.
AMY: I don't understand.
DOCTOR: Oh, er, well, you send Christmas cards out to everyone, and it's on their honour to send you a Christmas card back.
AMY: And, what, that's not how markets work normally?
DOCTOR: Not everywhere, no. I thought they were soldiers, but they're more like an arts and crafts commune, swapping goods as they're needed. They've got theatre and science and what I think is a kind of political singing.
AMY: And they don't know what warrior means. They've never had any wars.
DOCTOR: No. Martians learn to fight, to hunt animals for food, but they don't fight one another, at least not yet. It's er, well, it's not what I was expecting.
AMY: We could stay if you like, for a while.
DOCTOR: We need to get that second segment. It was what caused the earthquake, wasn't it? Wasn't it?
AMY: Something isn't right.
DOCTOR: Come on. We don't want anyone else to suffer.
AMY: But we can't just go up there and take it. Someone will see.
DOCTOR: Well, we'll just have to make sure they don't notice us.
ICE WARRIOR: Alien.
DOCTOR: Oh. Er, yes?
ICE WARRIOR: You and your female are under arrest.
ISSKAR: Go on, Doctor, guess.
DOCTOR: Er, twelve thousand.
ISSKAR: More.
DOCTOR: Thirteen thousand.
ISSKAR: More.
AMY: Forty eight million billion, fifteen thousand and six.
ISSKAR: Ah. (laughs) Fewer. The vast pyramid has employed nineteen thousand literate masons, six hundred carpenters and forty six overseers, as well as the providence of the old Gods.
DOCTOR: Hmn, yes, I recognise their influence in the apothem. It's built for the golden ratio, isn't it? A plus Bis to Aas Ais to B.
ISSKAR: Indeed, Doctor.
AMY: A ratio of one to one point six one eight oh three nine eight...
DOCTOR: More or less, yes.
ISSKAR: You are both literates.
DOCTOR: And numerates, Isskar. I've seen that ratio written all across the universe from sequences in DNA to the hearts of stars.
AMY: The Grace use it to measure integrals...
DOCTOR: I'm sure the Magistrate doesn't need to know.
AMY: Oh yes. Sorry.
ISSKAR: We understand the numbers, so the pyramid cannot be the cause of the earthquakes. Our engineers would not allow it.
DOCTOR: I'm sure they didn't mean to. You say earthquakes, plural.
ISSKAR: They started when our moons were half their weight. In the last few days there have been more of them. But with less effect, it is passing.
DOCTOR: Is it? You know the story of the Hubris of Jebb? A nut raining wet fire on his house for a year but he refused to admit it.
ISSKAR: Did the Old Gods teach your people astronomy too, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Actually we taught... Er, we taught ourselves. Though from the same first principles. Observation, evidence.
ISSKAR: (laughs.) The Ice Lords in the North should meet you. You're not like the reports.
DOCTOR: Not all aliens are the same, Isskar.
ISSKAR: No. But my own beadles described you as thieves.
AMY: They can't mean us.
ISSKAR: A male and a female without scales.
DOCTOR: You don't get many alien visitors around here, do you?
ISSKAR: No.
AMY: What is it?
DOCTOR: Most species are wary of strangers. It's a good survival instinct. We've been singled out.
ISSKAR: You'll understand if my beadles keep a watch on you.
DOCTOR: Oh, I understand perfectly.
ISSKAR: And you'll stay away from the vast pyramid. The building site is restricted.
AMY: But we have to get the sec...
DOCTOR: We understand, Magistrate Isskar.
AMY: But Doctor, we need the...
ISSKAR: Trespass will be punished severely.
DOCTOR: Yes, I rather thought it would. Thank you, Magistrate. You've been very kind. We've taken up far too much of your time and we should get on with our dawdling about. I'll bet there's some lovely boutiques as yet undiscovered where we can find some... postcards. Come on, Amy.
AMY: Oh. Thank you for the water.
ISSKAR: It was given freely.
AMY: I don't understand. He let us go.
DOCTOR: They're reasonable people, Amy. He was just giving us fair warning.
AMY: But you told him we wouldn't go near the pyramid.
DOCTOR: I said I understood. If we get caught they'll treat us severely.
AMY: But we don't have any choice.
DOCTOR: There's always a choice, Amy.
AMY: No there's not. There's going to be another earthquake!
DOCTOR: Not if we can help it. Come on.
AMY: But Doctor...
DOCTOR: What?
AMY: The building site? The entrance is over here.
DOCTOR: Oh. Right. Well, after you.
ICE WARRIOR: Get to the shelters. Move, quickly.
AMY: There's nobody left in here.
DOCTOR: Only an idiot goes into a building site in the middle of an earthquake. Come on, we need to be the other side of this fence.
AMY: There's always the door. It doesn't open.
DOCTOR: Here, let me try. One day I must fix myself another sonic screwdriver. It would save me so much time.
AMY: I thought you said we had to do this quietly.
DOCTOR: So I did. After you.
AMY: What if there are Martians in there?
DOCTOR: Then we'll tell them Isskar sent us.
AMY: But he didn't.
DOCTOR: No, but they don't need to know that. What?
AMY: My nose is tickly.
DOCTOR: That's because we're getting near the segment. Just have a bit of a climb.
AMY: No, it's not that. It's different. I think there's someone else here.
DOCTOR: Someone's coming. Hide. We'll let them go past then we'll carry on.
AMY: Okay.
ZARA: Get off me!
ICE WARRIOR: Trespassers will be punished severely.
ZARA: We're not doing anything. We're tourists. You don't do this to tourists.
AMY: But that's...
DOCTOR: Amy, wait! Come back.
AMY: We have to help her.
ICE WARRIOR: Save it for the beadle. He has more patience than me.
ZARA: But we just wanted to take a photograph. Isn't that right, Zinc?
ZINC: That's right.
ZARA: Zinc? You're choking him, you clumsy oaf.
ICE WARRIOR: I am trying not to, but he keeps struggling. If you'd both just...
AMY: Let them go!
DOCTOR: Amy, stop it, this won't do us any good. He's not trying to hurt them.
ICE WARRIOR: That's what I was trying to explain to the short man. You aliens are small, soft-boned and fragile.
DOCTOR: No - no, wait!
AMY: You killed him.
ZARA: You killed him! Well done, Zinc.
ZINC: He had it coming. Said I was small.
AMY: You killed him.
DOCTOR: Yes, he's dead, Amy. I think Isskar mistook us for these two. You must be the thieves.
ZINC: You should watch what you're accusing people of, Mister. I don't like name-calling. And I'm the one with the gun.
DOCTOR: Yes, so you are. Please let Amy go, she's nothing to you.
ZARA: (laughs) Amy. Have you got yourself a name?
AMY: I didn't say I liked it.
DOCTOR: You know these people, do you?
AMY: Her, not him.
ZINC: Oh, charming. You should be more like your big sister.
DOCTOR: You're sisters?
AMY: Not really.
ZARA: It's the simplest way to explain it.
ZINC: And you can see the family resemblance. Same eyes, same cheekbones, same clever school-bags.
DOCTOR: You're after the other three segments, are you?
ZARA: Not found any yet. Have you?
AMY: We've got one.
ZARA: That means the one here is mine. It's only fair.
DOCTOR: I'm sure there's enough segments for everyone.
ZARA: And you are...? Oh. Oh, it's you.
DOCTOR: Sorry, you've got me at a disadvantage. I'm the Doctor.
ZARA: I knew it. I Knew she'd pick you up. The Grace said he'd be trouble...
AMY: I needed an assistant.
ZARA: And so did I. But I didn't feel the need to hunt down the one guy who...
AMY: All right! He's been useful. He knows how to do this stuff.
DOCTOR: Er, Amy, we should be going.
ZINC: Yeah. They'll be back here soon enough. We can't be near the body.
ZARA: Let's go.
DOCTOR: Amy, come on. Amy, you can't stay here.
AMY: They killed him. They killed him.
DOCTOR: I know. But if we stay here they'll think it was us. Come on.
DOCTOR: Once we leave the cover of the scaffolding, everyone can see us.
ZINC: It looks like another... hundred metres to the top.
AMY: Ninety eight... So, ninety eight more of these... Oh, I guess they're too big to call steps?
DOCTOR: Yes well, little bracing exercise, good for the circulation.
ZARA: Oh, you're kidding.
DOCTOR: Ninety seven. And then we've got to work out an escape plan too.
ZARA: Oh, amateurs.
AMY: What's that meant to mean?
DOCTOR: I assume you have a plan, Mister... I'm sorry, I don't know your name.
ZINC: Harmonious Fourteen Zinc.
DOCTOR: Ah, from the Commune of the White Sun.
ZINC: Yeah, originally. Haven't been home in years. Why bother when you can go anywhere and when.
DOCTOR: I've always thought so.
ZINC: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Though I did like the White Sun's tree-houses. Spent a week in Hauldon. Mostly being accused of blotting out the sunlight, which was just an unhappy coincidence, but... apart from being imprisoned and threatened with various kinds of torture... lovely people, I thought.
ZINC: Yeah.
ZARA: So, you haven't told him, then?
AMY: I didn't think it would help.
ZARA: He'll find out soon enough.
AMY: Maybe.
ZARA: And he'll leave you to it, because you lied. He'll leave you.
AMY: He's not like your one.
ZARA: Zinc has taught me a lot.
AMY: I can see that. You're... well, I can see him in your eyes and how you move. Has he given you a name?
ZARA: What do I want a name for?
AMY: Everyone should have their own name. Isn't that right, Doctor?
DOCTOR: What's that?
AMY: She should have a name.
ZARA: I don't want a name.
ZINC: She's a construct. She's not real.
DOCTOR: But she's still a she. A name will help her build an identity, become someone real. So, starting with A.
AMY: But that's the same as me.
DOCTOR: All right, er... Z. Z, er... Zoe. I used to know a Zoe. Zinnia. Zillah. Zena. Er, Zelda, Zynab, Zara...
ZINC: Zara was my mum's name.
DOCTOR: It's a nice name. It means Princess.
ZARA: Oh, go on then, I'll have that one. Just to shut you up.
ICE WARRIOR: Stop.
AMY: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, I can see him. Need to get a move on. Sixty four steps to go.
AMY: He's faster than we are.
DOCTOR: Never seen Martians move so quickly. Must be the low gravity, their natural environment.
ZARA: So he'll catch us.
ZINC: I've still got my gun.
DOCTOR: Can I see that?
ZINC: You want to do the honours? Here.
DOCTOR: Whoops! Oh, butterfingers.
ZARA: You did that on purpose.
AMY: You would have used it again.
ZINC: My wife gave me that gun.
DOCTOR: How romantic. Sorry. Enough people have died.
ZINC: And you might have just killed us.
DOCTOR: Not if you've got an escape route. What do you use, if you don't mind my asking?
ZINC: I think you're in the same game. See this?
DOCTOR: A bracelet.
ZINC: It's a time ring. Picked it up on Barampa. The VP Party had it in a museum, thought it was just ceremonial. So I er, I borrowed it.
DOCTOR: I see. So why not materialise on the capstone itself, grab the segment and dash off again?
ZARA: Oh, that's what we've been trying to do.
ZINC: Something skews the coordinates. One time we found ourselves six weeks out, and in the middle of a desert.
AMY: Amateurs.
ZINC: Don't get cocky. I've only ever used this thing with two.
DOCTOR: A short hop won't hurt it. Drop us in the market. we have our own transport.
ZINC: What, some sort of a capsule?
DOCTOR: It's a retro thing. So what do you say? We are family after all.
ZARA: Long as I get this segment.
AMY: Yes, you get the segment.
DOCTOR: Good. Come on, we're almost there.
ZARA: No we're not.
ICE WARRIOR: Stop, or I will shoot you.
DOCTOR: Just climb.
AMY: My head. It's in my head.
ZARA: Got to... got to get nearer.
DOCTOR: Almost there. Just keep going.
ICE WARRIOR: Your final warning.
ZINC: Get a move on!
ZARA: I can't!
DOCTOR: The capstone. What's happened to it?
ICE WARRIOR: There is nowhere you can run.
ZARA: I can't get near it.
AMY: But it's not there. It's out of reach.
ZINC: But I can see it. I can... Ow! Ah!
DOCTOR: Careful. It's a long way down.
ZINC: Yeah. And look. From here you can see the shockwaves, rippling through the canals and waterways.
AMY: The segment is causing the earthquake.
DOCTOR: We have to stop it.
ZARA: But we can't touch it.
DOCTOR: There's something wrong with the segments, isn't there? That's why you needed to fetch them back in.
ZARA: They're decaying. Their powers are warping.
ICE WARRIOR: Raise your arms. I will shoot any one of you.
DOCTOR: It's imploding. Forming a gravity well. Maybe a black hole.
ZINC: It'll destroy Mars.
ICE WARRIOR: You are my prisoners. You will not destroy Mars.
DOCTOR: Oh, Mars is the least of our worries. If the Key to Time collapses, the universe is finished.

elements.text: [Part Two]
You will step back from the capstone with your arms raised.
Whatever you say. There's no need to shoot anyone.
You killed Asskor.
Not - not me. He did.
Me? It's his fingerprints on the gun. I can explain about the fingerprints.
Doctor!
Leave the capstone. I will shoot you.
It's the capstone that's causing the earthquakes. Really, we're only trying to help.
I will call Magistrate Isskar.
Good. That makes sense.
To tell him I have taken you prisoner. A message for Magistrate Isskar...
I can reach it. Amy, if we reach it together...
Yes.
Amy and Zara cry out.
Stop!
Don't, don't, don't worry mate, it's not like they can pinch it from right in front of you, is it?
Both of you, wait. The segment's created a gravity well. Removing it could be like pulling a plug, and we're standing right on the plug hole.
But I can feel it. (screams)
Zara!
It won't let you touch it. It's setting your fingers alight.
See? Told you.
It's going to be all right. We'll get your hands seen to.
What have you done?
We've stopped the earthquakes, obviously. I hope there's a reward.
The Martians don't work like that, Zinc.
You have stopped the earthquakes, but where is the capstone?
Here, in this crystal. It's holding a black hole at bay. I can feel it pressing against the sides. Such a lot of power. Mine now.
Zara, you can't leave with it, not yet. Let me get back to my ship. Maybe I can repair the damage then you can go.
Oh, you'll allow that, will you?
He's trying to help. What's happened to you?
You were different too after you got your first segment.
Was I?
And she's got two segments now.
What?
You lied.
We picked up the first one on Erratoon. Nobody there's going to miss it.
You will give me the crystal.
Will I?
Do as he says, Zara. He's got the gun.
Go on, Martian. Do your worst.
Now, wait a...
Ice Warrior gun fired.
Is that all you've got?
The segment must be protecting her.
That's a neat trick. Probably worth something.
Oh, can you only think about money?
It's all that really makes a difference, sweetheart.
Yeah, I think I've outgrown you now, Zinc.
Huh? Whatâ€™s that meant to mean? Hey! That's mine.
With the time ring, I don't need you at all.
Now, wait.
Zara, don't do this. You're condemning us all.
I know, Goodbye.
Wibble.
Where did she go?
We don't have time. Quick, down the pyramid.
We're right on top of the earthquakes.
The pyramid is going to collapse!
They all cry out.
This is magistrate Isskar. You aliens are under arrest.
Brilliant, Isskar.
How do we get aboard?
The forcefield is extending.
Great. Amy, Zinc, we have to jump.
I don't feel any safer.
We need to fly into the gravity well. If you don't it'll tear us apart.
Alien, stay back from the controls.
You're going to kill everyone on board.
Listen to him. He knows about this kind of thing. Isskar, please.
Let him take the helm.
Thank you. Right. Er, gears, clutch, stereo radio, so this one must be the thrust. Oh!
It's not working!
You will not survive either.
Oh ye of little... faith.
Well done, Doctor.
That's better.
We're safe?
We're in a holding pattern about two hundred metres above the ground which is ripping itself to pieces. Enough fuel for maybe an hour, then it gets a bit tricky.
You will step away from the controls now.
Oh, don't mention it. It was given freely.
It is an unprovoked attack. We shall repay the debt upon you.
Isskar, it's too late for that. You need to start an evacuation. Get everyone out of the town.
Our engineers will investigate.
There's a black hole on your doorstep. Look at what it's already done.
The canals are boiling away.
It's the heat trying to equalise.
What?
I did spatial anomalies at school.
Can't we do something?
We can get people away from here. Isskar, you have to listen... Ow!
Doctor!
You will undo what you have done.
It's too late for that, I'm sorry.
But why?
If I denounce them, can I get a more lenient sentence?
Zinc, that won't help.
I just want to clarify my options. Well?
Perhaps a less arduous death.
Er... I'm sure we can do a bit better than that, huh?
Magistrate, orders from the Ice Lord. All ships are required to assist those still on the ground.
At least someone's using their intelligence.
Take us down. I need an escort to come with me on the ground. Watch these three. Shoot the female if they try anything.
Hey, why me?
You have the least to say.
That's so unfair.
Try nothing.
I was just saying.
So how do we get out of this one?
I thought you were going to denounce us.
I just wanted to clarify my options.
Nothing personal.
Hey, you know how it is in this game.
We need to escape, get back to the Tardis.
And then you can heal the black hole. Doctor?
I think it's too late for that, Amy.
But the Martians. So many of them are going to die.
I know! I know.
And us if we stick around.
Yes, so, we're almost on the ground now. Have you done much guarding before?
You will not get past me, alien.
I wouldn't dream of it. It's just - you're holding your sonic blaster the wrong way round.
Ice Warrior gun fires.
One at a time. One at a time. There is room for all of you on the skiff if you do not push.
Magistrate?
I am a little busy.
But the aliens, they've escaped.
What?
Not all of them. Just the two guilty ones.
This one was recaptured.
I surrendered. I said I'm not with those other two.
Get after them. They must not escape.
They'll be heading for their capsule. I think it's in the market.
Do as he says.
Yes, Magistrate.
See? I'm not with them.
And now you wish for your reward?
Well, I won't say no if there's one going.
I said a less arduous death.
What? Oh. Yeah, funny. Good to keep a sense of humour when your whole world's going to... Oh, wait. I can be useful. I can tell you all about the Key to Ti...
Ice Warrior gun. Scream, thud.
We will repay this debt. I swear it.
One good thing about all this. They're all too busy to chase after us.
But Harmonious Fourteen Zinc.
He's made his choice. Come on. The Tardis is just up here.
But we can't leave them like this. We should stay, try to help.
There's nothing we can do, really.
Stop. Stop.
And they don't seem all that keen on our helping.
Tardis door opens.
But it's wrong to just leave them.
I know, Amy, I know.
Stop.
Tardis door closes.
Stop.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Right. Oh, sorry about the bumpy take-off. The gravity well passes right through the middle of Mars.
She knew, didn't she?
Explains why Zinc's time ring kept being knocked off course.
She knew what it would do, didn't she, Doctor?
I think she must have had some idea, Amy. The Key to Time boasts terrible power. People can't help being drawn to it.
So it's not her fault?
No, it's her fault.
But I wanted that segment just as much as she did. I wanted that power too.
Maybe. But you're also horrified by what it did.
The Martians are going to die.
The gravity well will work itself out in time, but it will change conditions on the planet, so they'll have to move somewhere new. They'll work that out soon enough.
So it's going to be all right?
No. Not all right. Millions of them will die before they'll admit there's a long-term problem. They're a brilliant culture in so many ways but pride can blind even the best of us.
Beeps.
What is it?
Er... all kind of spatial disturbances. Holes being eaten in Time.
It's Zara.
Or the remaining segments. They're all starting to decay. That's why you and Zara have to find them.
Yes.
You should have told me.
I di... I didn't think you'd want to know.
That the Key to Time is collapsing and with it the whole of the universe?
And it's your fault.
I see. That's why the Grace didn't want me involved.
I... I thought you'd be the best person to help. It would... balance things out, make them right again.
What did I do?
You put the key together without the sixth segment.
There were rather pressing reasons for it at the time. We had to mock up the final piece. It seemed to work okay.
But that's not how the segments work. They depend on one another.
A design flaw.
Maybe. The Grace never thought anyone would try something so reckless as substituting a segment.
So, I caused some kind of chain reaction and all the Charged Vacuum Emboitements and sticking
plaster couldn't put it back together again.
It's all unravelling.
So the places where the segments are hidden are in immediate danger. And they're only a fraction ahead of everyone else, but that means we've got not long left.
The world where we met, where the Grace stopped the rain?
Where they stopped Time.
That's the furthest into the future any of the segments are hidden, and sixty six minutes from the end of time.
Sixty six minutes? Not... well, quite a lot more millennia than that. And you can't hold off the rain for ever.
The Grace have finite powers, entropy has set in.
They won't know what's hit them.
If we could find Zara...
She'd cause us more trouble. No, I think we go and find the remaining segments and then see where we are.
But I can't touch any more segments. I'll end up like her.
You're not the same as Zara, Amy. You're your own person.
But if I touch another segment then I'll go...
I know. But it could hardly make anything worse.
The Tardis materialises, door opens.
So, which way do you think? We want to just grab the thing and go.
I Know, but I'm tickly all over the place. It's up here and over there and underneath us. I don't understand.
There must be some kind of echo, perhaps to do with whatever the castle walls are made of. If we wander around a bit, you should get a clearer signal.
So you know where we are this time?

Somewhere on a ring-world called Safeplace about sixteen thousand years since we were on Mars, and maybe twice as many light years. The last time I was in the area the whole galaxy was at war. I think there's been three or four generations since the Neek Armistice was signed. We're in the district inhabited by the Valdigians, one of your more civilised insect-like species.
You should write a book or something.
And give away all my secrets? I like to retain a certain hint of mystery.
Hence those symbols on your collar. I'm the Doctor, I'm the man of mystery.
You know, you've got a lot more sarcastic since we first met.
I have a good teacher. It's not working. The signal is still all over the place.
Well, we'll keep going. I'm sure something will turn up. Ah. These are Valdigians. Guards, going by the stripes on their wings.
Intruders. Poisoners. Heretics. You are under arrest.
See? Told you.
I think it must be a gift.
The ice should bring down the fever. You can't die, Lady Mesca. Your people need you. I need you.
I know. But I have no choice.
No. No! Wembik's faction are liars.
No.
Yes, of course they have done this. Who else could it have been?
Thetris, we are as horrified as you are. But perhaps Mesca is just unwell. The pressure incurred by these proceedings. It would not be unheard of.
Unwell? Unwell? She is dying. Wembik. You and your faction have cursed her, and you will not deny it.
That is quite an allegation. Did Mesca witness this cursing? Did she?
I saw nothing.
You see?
Do not try to speak. You must save your strength.
Thetris, you cannot start a war.
But I will not let this stand. They have cursed you.
Not us. Maybe it was them.
Poisoners. Aliens. Warmakers. Wingless freaks.
Hello. You're Valdigians, aren't you? I'm the Doctor, this is Amy. We just happen to be passing on a sort of treasure hunt.
You can offer us some water if you like.
Strangers in the castle.
It's an outrage. I shall have the orderlies flogged.
We don't mean to intrude, but as I say we're on this sort of treasure hunt. Forgive me, but your friend there looks a bit peaky. Maybe I can...
Keep back from her.
This creature must have cursed her. It stands to reason.
Ah, but for what reason? I know it's a bit of a coincidence, but we've only just arrived.
We've been singled out again, haven't we? Just because we're strangers.
Occupational hazard. Please, I'm a doctor. I really think that I can help.
You want to sell me a counter-charm?
It's offered freely.
Ha! It has to be a trick. Shall take the smaller one to be tortured. We will find the truth.
Doctor?
There's no need for that. I'm happy to help if I can.
Take her, Wembik. Find out what they've done.
Please, she's entirely innocent. We're just here looking for an artefact that will do you all terrible harm.
It will be my pleasure to obey, Thettris.
(receding) Doctor, I don't want to be tortured! Doctor...
Please, she doesn't know anything. She's not even a day old.
You will apply the counter-charm, Doctor, or I'll have you tortured too.
I won't help you until you let her go.
Then your friend will die!
Please.
All right, all right, let's see what we can do.
I don't know your kind of biology, creature. But we will start with the extremities and work our way inwards. You need not worry. The blades are heated, so they will be sterilised.
It's not going to do any good, you know.
You think you can remain silent?
No, but I don't know anything.
So you Say.
Like the Doctor said, we're looking for something that could do you terrible harm. Oh, how can I convince you? I'll do anything.
You can tell me how you cursed the Lady Mesca. Now, this is just to start with. A pin prick. (whirring) Didn't you feel that?
Yes. It prickles a bit. Oh, careful you don't burn yourself.
I will make you scream.
Ooo! That hurts. Is that what you want?
Do not mock me.
Hello. I'm the Doctor. It's going to be all right.
You musin't let there be a war.
Oh, we'll get you on the mend soon enough then you can put things right and let my friend go. What's your name?
Mesca.
Hello, Mesca.
She is the Lady Mesca Amuntik, soon to be mother to the King.
You're pregnant?
Mmm. My son is eight orbits old. He and Wembik's boy are the two contenders for the crown.
I see. Raise your... arms. That's good. And the next pair. So you're here to sort out which one it is.
The castle has always served to resolve disputes, ever since Safeplace was constructed.
It's a neutral space. You should be safe here. Then you're suddenly struck down.
Wembik has dark powers.
Yes, she's not a people person, is she. You've not seen her wielding some unlikely artefact, have you? As if it's where her dark powers come from?
You mean like a magical wand?
Could be shaped like anything, but it would be the source of her magic.
Hmm. I don't think she has anything like that.
Ah well, just a thought. And who are you?
I am Thetris!
Hello, Thetris. Look, you can see I'm helping. Please release my friend.
Mesca must not die. I'd do anything!
Oh, are you two more than just colleagues?
He is the Captain of our Ceremonial Guard.
Yes, I like the uniform.
And we were to be married after the Kingship had been agreed.
It was to be kept secret until then. We did not wish it to confuse the discussion here. But Doctor, I will go to war for Mesca. Wembik's faction will not win, however they have done this.
I don't want there to be a war.
Civil wars are always the most brutal. And isn't it rather missing the point of living somewhere called Safeplace?
But I must do something! I cannot watch you die like this.
Oh, don't cancel the wedding yet. Mesca is going to be fine.
But, but you've not applied a charm.
No, but here, below her ap...
Oh, we are not meant to look at the dorsal regions.

Then that's why you won't have seen this. A bruise with two pinpricks in the centre. That's some kind of bite. Snake, or snake-ish, anyway. And I think I've got just the thing. Er. Oh, hold this a second.
What is it?
A yo-yo. Er, that's a King of Hearts. Ah, here we are.
Still nothing?
Well, I can feel that it's sharp.
But we've not even raised your heart rate.
Sorry. This must be quite frustrating.
I don't know what we're doing wrong.
Maybe I'm just the wrong sort of creature. It probably just works on Valdigians.
I've never tortured a Valdigian.
Oh. Well, I'm, I'm sure you're a good person, really.
I've never done anything like this before. It's stupid. It's not me.
No.
But the chance for my son to be King. The thought of it.
It tickles.
Yes. It tickles.
I know that feeling. I've been close to power.
You want it too?
No. I've seen what it can do.
Well, it's only ceremonial power I'm after.
Oh. Well, that's all right, then.
Honestly. We're the descendants of refugees who've survived the war, and we're on a ring-world where everything's plentiful. We don't need Kings any more.
But you still have them anyway?

You really have just arrived, haven't you? Our law says that a King can only rule from the age of twenty three. Until then a provisional government keeps the peace, and gets involved only when it has to.
And does it have to? You said everything was plentiful.
Exactly. We don't want leaders. So, we elect a child who agrees to stand down at the age of twenty two. In return they get a generous pension for the rest of their life.
So you never have a King.
And only as much government as is absolutely necessary.
So you're going to war over an entirely meaningless role?
It's not meaningless, it's symbolic. And I don't mind if it's not my son in the role, so long as it's not Mesca's. She's always had everything her way, even when we were larvae.
So that's why you poisoned her.
I didn't say I did.
Well, maybe you didn't do it yourself, but I think you know who did.
Now, listen, alien.
Door opens.
Release the alien creature.
Thetris, I've not finished with her.
But the Doctor must have cured Mesca.
We can but hope.
No. She's barely conscious, but he says he has the answer and I want you there. Release her.
Oh, all right. You'd better undo my straps. Ow. My arm hurts.
Oh! It hurts you now.
No, look. A bruise. Oh, come on. The Doctor should see this too.
Just concentrate on breathing, Mesca. In, and out. In, and out. We'll have you better soon. Amy. You're all right.
Yes, I guess. Though I've got this bruise on my arm.
Let me see. That's interesting. You're becoming more susceptible to pain. Must be part of the learning process.
Oh. That's good, is it?
It's a bit tricky, actually.
It means they can hurt me.
It means I could poison you.
Oh, and you were going to do that, were you?
The Doctor says his anti-charm is made from snake venom.
That's either very clever or very not clever.
It will kill the girl.

It's an anti-toxin based on the poison in the wound. I had a kit in my pocket which identified the toxin at once. Amiscalia, venom of a local snake-like thing. But Thetris is keen we try it first before letting Mesca drink it.
You said it would not harm your friend.
Well, she was impervious to earthquakes, but now...
Give it to her.
I'm not sure that's a good idea.
I don't mind. If it helps, I'll take it.
But it's made of poison.
You see? He admits it.
Give your friend the charm, Doctor, or I will kill you both.
I can't, not if she's changing herself.
Oh, give it here.
Amy, don't, it could kill you.
And he'll kill us both if I don't. I'm sure it will be fine. I trust you.
Thetris, please.
Ugh! It, it tastes of... I don't know what it tastes of.
Poison, probably. How do you feel?
Weird. Not good. Oh. I think I should sit down.
You're very pale, and trembling. Amy, I'm sorry, but I think you're reacting...
Oh! Wow! Oh. It hurts.
Somebody please, get her some water.
Doctor, it's all right. Don't look like that. It's all right.
Is she going to die?
I just wanted Mesca to be safe.
It .. it... It tickles. It's okay. I'm okay, see? It's easy.
Give the anti-charm to Mesca.
It won't work as quickly on her, but it will work.
Tastes of curdled milk and mead.
That's what it tastes of? Ugh! Where's that water?
Doctor, you have... you have saved her.
Yes, I rather think I have. I take it we can go now?
When she recovers, yes. Until then, you will be our guests.
Thetris?
Excuse me, Doctor. My lieutenant calls me.
I wonder if the segment's broken open? We don't have any time.
What is it, Lieutenant?
Ringer sensors tell us they've picked up spacecraft coming this way.
To the castle?
Best intercept course, yes. But they are not responding to communication protocols. That is an act of war.
Stand down the defences. They're expected.
They are the pilgrims?
They must be. Lady Zara would not lie.
We must not let them live.
Something is happening. Let me know if the pilgrims make contact.
Sir.
Please, we're not your enemies. We're just looking at the paintings. One of them could be what we're looking for.
But you mean to kill us. You're the ones who poisoned Lady Mesca.
We don't know that, Wembik. We don't know who did this to me.
I do.
You know who tried to kill the Lady Mesca?
You worked it out?
It was Wembik, wasn't it?
She lies. I admitted no such thing.
Amy?
But you're the one who'd profit from Mesca being dead. You're the one who could have moved around the castle whereas we would have been noticed.
And I'm guessing you know a bit about snakes.
She wrote a monograph on handling them. Lady Wembik, I condemn you to die.
But I had to do it. Mesca's son can't be the King.
Er, does anyone hear that?
Spaceship engines.
You don't have to have the war now, do you, Thetris? As long as Wembik admits that she's lost.
Yes. We can agree something like that, can't we?
I condemn you to die.
Look, I think you should all listen.
Doctor, don't try to stop me.
But that was the sound of a spaceship.
Sentries! Sentries! There are alien creatures.
See? If only people would listen.
The pilgrims.
All are welcome to this castle, Thetris. It is a place of peace.
Yes. We must welcome them.
We can at least see what they want.
But those are Martians!
Everyone take cover. They're really not coming in peace.
Ice Warrior guns fired.
You will surrender. You will lay down your weapons and surrender.
What are they?
They're Martians.
They're not Martians any more.
You will surrender to the Ice Warriors, or we shall kill all of you.
And they just happen to turn up where we happen to be. It can't be a coincidence.
The Doctor and Amy will surrender themselves or we shall continue to destroy your people.
See? Oh well. Best find out what it's all about. Mesca?
Yes, Doctor?
The Ice Warriors, they really don't like the heat.
Right.
Come on, Amy. All right, all right, we come quietly. Just don't harm anyone else. Hello. You're a long way from home.
Yes, Doctor. We are.
I know that voice.
Doctor, look. He got old.
And he's been promoted to Ice Lord. Hello, Isskar. It's been quite a while.
Yes. But I would follow you to the end of Time, to repay my people's debt.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
ICE WARRIOR: You will step back from the capstone with your arms raised.
DOCTOR: Whatever you say. There's no need to shoot anyone.
ICE WARRIOR: You killed Asskor.
ZINC: Not - not me. He did.
DOCTOR: Me? It's his fingerprints on the gun. I can explain about the fingerprints.
AMY: Doctor!
ICE WARRIOR: Leave the capstone. I will shoot you.
DOCTOR: It's the capstone that's causing the earthquakes. Really, we're only trying to help.
ICE WARRIOR: I will call Magistrate Isskar.
DOCTOR: Good. That makes sense.
ICE WARRIOR: To tell him I have taken you prisoner. A message for Magistrate Isskar...
ZARA: I can reach it. Amy, if we reach it together...
AMY: Yes.
ICE WARRIOR: Stop!
ZINC: Don't, don't, don't worry mate, it's not like they can pinch it from right in front of you, is it?
DOCTOR: Both of you, wait. The segment's created a gravity well. Removing it could be like pulling a plug, and we're standing right on the plug hole.
ZARA: But I can feel it. (screams)
AMY: Zara!
DOCTOR: It won't let you touch it. It's setting your fingers alight.
AMY: See? Told you.
DOCTOR: It's going to be all right. We'll get your hands seen to.
ICE WARRIOR: What have you done?
ZINC: We've stopped the earthquakes, obviously. I hope there's a reward.
DOCTOR: The Martians don't work like that, Zinc.
ICE WARRIOR: You have stopped the earthquakes, but where is the capstone?
ZARA: Here, in this crystal. It's holding a black hole at bay. I can feel it pressing against the sides. Such a lot of power. Mine now.
DOCTOR: Zara, you can't leave with it, not yet. Let me get back to my ship. Maybe I can repair the damage then you can go.
ZARA: Oh, you'll allow that, will you?
AMY: He's trying to help. What's happened to you?
DOCTOR: You were different too after you got your first segment.
AMY: Was I?
ZINC: And she's got two segments now.
DOCTOR: What?
AMY: You lied.
ZARA: We picked up the first one on Erratoon. Nobody there's going to miss it.
ICE WARRIOR: You will give me the crystal.
ZARA: Will I?
DOCTOR: Do as he says, Zara. He's got the gun.
ZARA: Go on, Martian. Do your worst.
ZINC: Now, wait a...
ZARA: Is that all you've got?
DOCTOR: The segment must be protecting her.
ZINC: That's a neat trick. Probably worth something.
ZARA: Oh, can you only think about money?
ZINC: It's all that really makes a difference, sweetheart.
ZARA: Yeah, I think I've outgrown you now, Zinc.
ZINC: Huh? Whatâ€™s that meant to mean? Hey! That's mine.
ZARA: With the time ring, I don't need you at all.
ZINC: Now, wait.
DOCTOR: Zara, don't do this. You're condemning us all.
ZARA: I know, Goodbye.
ICE WARRIOR: Where did she go?
DOCTOR: We don't have time. Quick, down the pyramid.
ZINC: We're right on top of the earthquakes.
DOCTOR: The pyramid is going to collapse!
ISSKAR: This is magistrate Isskar. You aliens are under arrest.
DOCTOR: Brilliant, Isskar.
AMY: How do we get aboard?
ICE WARRIOR: The forcefield is extending.
DOCTOR: Great. Amy, Zinc, we have to jump.
ZINC: I don't feel any safer.
DOCTOR: We need to fly into the gravity well. If you don't it'll tear us apart.
ICE WARRIOR: Alien, stay back from the controls.
DOCTOR: You're going to kill everyone on board.
AMY: Listen to him. He knows about this kind of thing. Isskar, please.
ISSKAR: Let him take the helm.
DOCTOR: Thank you. Right. Er, gears, clutch, stereo radio, so this one must be the thrust. Oh!
AMY: It's not working!
ISSKAR: You will not survive either.
DOCTOR: Oh ye of little... faith.
ZINC: Well done, Doctor.
DOCTOR: That's better.
AMY: We're safe?
DOCTOR: We're in a holding pattern about two hundred metres above the ground which is ripping itself to pieces. Enough fuel for maybe an hour, then it gets a bit tricky.
ISSKAR: You will step away from the controls now.
DOCTOR: Oh, don't mention it. It was given freely.
ISSKAR: It is an unprovoked attack. We shall repay the debt upon you.
DOCTOR: Isskar, it's too late for that. You need to start an evacuation. Get everyone out of the town.
ISSKAR: Our engineers will investigate.
DOCTOR: There's a black hole on your doorstep. Look at what it's already done.
ISSKAR: The canals are boiling away.
ZINC: It's the heat trying to equalise.
DOCTOR: What?
ZINC: I did spatial anomalies at school.
AMY: Can't we do something?
DOCTOR: We can get people away from here. Isskar, you have to listen... Ow!
AMY: Doctor!
ISSKAR: You will undo what you have done.
DOCTOR: It's too late for that, I'm sorry.
ISSKAR: But why?
ZINC: If I denounce them, can I get a more lenient sentence?
DOCTOR: Zinc, that won't help.
ZINC: I just want to clarify my options. Well?
ISSKAR: Perhaps a less arduous death.
ZINC: Er... I'm sure we can do a bit better than that, huh?
ICE WARRIOR: Magistrate, orders from the Ice Lord. All ships are required to assist those still on the ground.
DOCTOR: At least someone's using their intelligence.
ISSKAR: Take us down. I need an escort to come with me on the ground. Watch these three. Shoot the female if they try anything.
AMY: Hey, why me?
ISSKAR: You have the least to say.
AMY: That's so unfair.
ICE WARRIOR: Try nothing.
AMY: I was just saying.
ZINC: So how do we get out of this one?
AMY: I thought you were going to denounce us.
ZINC: I just wanted to clarify my options.
DOCTOR: Nothing personal.
ZINC: Hey, you know how it is in this game.
DOCTOR: We need to escape, get back to the Tardis.
AMY: And then you can heal the black hole. Doctor?
DOCTOR: I think it's too late for that, Amy.
AMY: But the Martians. So many of them are going to die.
DOCTOR: I know! I know.
ZINC: And us if we stick around.
DOCTOR: Yes, so, we're almost on the ground now. Have you done much guarding before?
ICE WARRIOR: You will not get past me, alien.
DOCTOR: I wouldn't dream of it. It's just - you're holding your sonic blaster the wrong way round.
ISSKAR: One at a time. One at a time. There is room for all of you on the skiff if you do not push.
ICE WARRIOR: Magistrate?
ISSKAR: I am a little busy.
ICE WARRIOR: But the aliens, they've escaped.
ISSKAR: What?
ZINC: Not all of them. Just the two guilty ones.
ICE WARRIOR: This one was recaptured.
ZINC: I surrendered. I said I'm not with those other two.
ISSKAR: Get after them. They must not escape.
ZINC: They'll be heading for their capsule. I think it's in the market.
ISSKAR: Do as he says.
ICE WARRIOR: Yes, Magistrate.
ZINC: See? I'm not with them.
ISSKAR: And now you wish for your reward?
ZINC: Well, I won't say no if there's one going.
ISSKAR: I said a less arduous death.
ZINC: What? Oh. Yeah, funny. Good to keep a sense of humour when your whole world's going to... Oh, wait. I can be useful. I can tell you all about the Key to Ti...
ISSKAR: We will repay this debt. I swear it.
DOCTOR: One good thing about all this. They're all too busy to chase after us.
AMY: But Harmonious Fourteen Zinc.
DOCTOR: He's made his choice. Come on. The Tardis is just up here.
AMY: But we can't leave them like this. We should stay, try to help.
DOCTOR: There's nothing we can do, really.
ICE WARRIOR: Stop. Stop.
DOCTOR: And they don't seem all that keen on our helping.
AMY: But it's wrong to just leave them.
DOCTOR: I know, Amy, I know.
ICE WARRIOR: Stop.
ICE WARRIOR: Stop.
DOCTOR: Right. Oh, sorry about the bumpy take-off. The gravity well passes right through the middle of Mars.
AMY: She knew, didn't she?
DOCTOR: Explains why Zinc's time ring kept being knocked off course.
AMY: She knew what it would do, didn't she, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I think she must have had some idea, Amy. The Key to Time boasts terrible power. People can't help being drawn to it.
AMY: So it's not her fault?
DOCTOR: No, it's her fault.
AMY: But I wanted that segment just as much as she did. I wanted that power too.
DOCTOR: Maybe. But you're also horrified by what it did.
AMY: The Martians are going to die.
DOCTOR: The gravity well will work itself out in time, but it will change conditions on the planet, so they'll have to move somewhere new. They'll work that out soon enough.
AMY: So it's going to be all right?
DOCTOR: No. Not all right. Millions of them will die before they'll admit there's a long-term problem. They're a brilliant culture in so many ways but pride can blind even the best of us.
AMY: What is it?
DOCTOR: Er... all kind of spatial disturbances. Holes being eaten in Time.
AMY: It's Zara.
DOCTOR: Or the remaining segments. They're all starting to decay. That's why you and Zara have to find them.
AMY: Yes.
DOCTOR: You should have told me.
AMY: I di... I didn't think you'd want to know.
DOCTOR: That the Key to Time is collapsing and with it the whole of the universe?
AMY: And it's your fault.
DOCTOR: I see. That's why the Grace didn't want me involved.
AMY: I... I thought you'd be the best person to help. It would... balance things out, make them right again.
DOCTOR: What did I do?
AMY: You put the key together without the sixth segment.
DOCTOR: There were rather pressing reasons for it at the time. We had to mock up the final piece. It seemed to work okay.
AMY: But that's not how the segments work. They depend on one another.
DOCTOR: A design flaw.
AMY: Maybe. The Grace never thought anyone would try something so reckless as substituting a segment.
DOCTOR: So, I caused some kind of chain reaction and all the Charged Vacuum Emboitements and sticking
DOCTOR: plaster couldn't put it back together again.
AMY: It's all unravelling.
DOCTOR: So the places where the segments are hidden are in immediate danger. And they're only a fraction ahead of everyone else, but that means we've got not long left.
AMY: The world where we met, where the Grace stopped the rain?
DOCTOR: Where they stopped Time.
AMY: That's the furthest into the future any of the segments are hidden, and sixty six minutes from the end of time.
DOCTOR: Sixty six minutes? Not... well, quite a lot more millennia than that. And you can't hold off the rain for ever.
AMY: The Grace have finite powers, entropy has set in.
DOCTOR: They won't know what's hit them.
AMY: If we could find Zara...
DOCTOR: She'd cause us more trouble. No, I think we go and find the remaining segments and then see where we are.
AMY: But I can't touch any more segments. I'll end up like her.
DOCTOR: You're not the same as Zara, Amy. You're your own person.
AMY: But if I touch another segment then I'll go...
DOCTOR: I know. But it could hardly make anything worse.
DOCTOR: So, which way do you think? We want to just grab the thing and go.
AMY: I Know, but I'm tickly all over the place. It's up here and over there and underneath us. I don't understand.
DOCTOR: There must be some kind of echo, perhaps to do with whatever the castle walls are made of. If we wander around a bit, you should get a clearer signal.
AMY: So you know where we are this time?
DOCTOR: Somewhere on a ring-world called Safeplace about sixteen thousand years since we were on Mars, and maybe twice as many light years. The last time I was in the area the whole galaxy was at war. I think there's been three or four generations since the Neek Armistice was signed. We're in the district inhabited by the Valdigians, one of your more civilised insect-like species.
AMY: You should write a book or something.
DOCTOR: And give away all my secrets? I like to retain a certain hint of mystery.
AMY: Hence those symbols on your collar. I'm the Doctor, I'm the man of mystery.
DOCTOR: You know, you've got a lot more sarcastic since we first met.
AMY: I have a good teacher. It's not working. The signal is still all over the place.
DOCTOR: Well, we'll keep going. I'm sure something will turn up. Ah. These are Valdigians. Guards, going by the stripes on their wings.
VALDIGIAN: Intruders. Poisoners. Heretics. You are under arrest.
DOCTOR: See? Told you.
AMY: I think it must be a gift.
